cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who plays max voice in a goofy movie
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine who plays Max's voice in "A Goofy Movie," I need to recall the cast of the film. "A Goofy Movie" is an animated film released in 1995, featuring characters from the Disney universe. Max Goof is the son of Goofy, and I need to identify the actor who provided the voice for this character. 

After considering the cast, I remember that the character of Max Goof was voiced by an actor known for his work in both animation and live-action. The voice actor for Max is also recognized for his contributions to other animated films and television shows.

Answer: Jason Marsden.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who plays max voice in a goofy movie
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- "A Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n', 'Most of the main voice cast from "Goof Troop" reprised their roles in "A Goofy Movie", including Bill Farmer as Goofy, Jim Cummings as Pete, and Rob Paulsen as PJ. To conform to his difference in age, Max was played by Jason Marsden, who was in high school at the time, replacing Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the character\'s voice actor. Alternatively, Aaron Lohr did Max\'s singing voice. Other cast members included Kellie Martin as Roxanne, Jenna von Oÿ as Stacey, and Pauly Shore as Bobby Zimuruski. Farmer, who spent 43 days recording dialogue over the span of 2-and-a-half years, was initially asked by Jeffrey Katzenberg to give Goofy a regular speaking voice as opposed to the character\'s signature, cartoonish voice, much to the confusion of Farmer, who insisted that audiences wanted to hear the Goofy they were all familiar with. After recording lines in this manner for a week-and-a-half, according to Farmer, Michael Eisner and Roy E. Disney told Farmer to speak in Goofy\'s original voice, after which the dialogue was rerecorded as such. R&B artist Tevin Campbell provided the singing voice for Powerline, recording the songs "Stand Out" and "I2I". Campbell recorded the songs in front of a green screen while performing his own choreography. The film is dedicated to Pat Buttram, who voiced the emcee at possum park, as he died after finishing voice work for the film.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Mardsen as Max Goof\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof\n', 'WatchMojo.com placed the Nostalgia Critic at #2 on their Top 10 YouTube Movie Critics list. Jacob Davich, who portrayed Linus in the film, "The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl", highly praised the Critic\'s review of the film. Both Bill Farmer, the voice of Goofy, and Jason Marsden, the voice of Max, praised Channel Awesome after watching the Critic\'s editorial, "Is Goofy Secretly Badass?" Animation director Ralph Bakshi praised the review of "Cool World", finding it "very funny". On August 27, 2017, the Critic did a crossover with fellow Channel Awesome critic, Nash Bozard. For "Here There Be Dragons", Bozard\'s review series about fantasy films and adaptations, the Critic and Nash reviewed the short-lived Syfy series "The Dresden Files". Jim Butcher, the author who wrote the novel series on which the series was based, seemed to react positively, tweeting "AHAHAHAHAHAHAHA ICANTSTOPLAUGHINGHAHAHAHAHAH".\n', 'BULLET::::- Maximilian "Max" Goof" (voiced by Dana Hill), is the son and only child of Goofy. He is 11½ years old, and is in the same grade as his best friend P.J. at their junior high school. While he is generally active, alert and friendly, he can also be very cunning and/or coercive when pushed or tricked, sometimes even on par with Pete. He loves his dad, and is close to him, but wishes he would be a little more normal, feeling at times embarrassed by his father\'s clumsy and doting behavior. His interests in the series include skateboarding, video games, rock music, girls, and outwitting bullies.\n', 'BULLET::::- G. G. "Goofy" Goof (voiced by Bill Farmer) is the single father of Max Goof. In the pilot episode, he and his son move next door to the Petes from their trailer home in another city. Goofy\'s biggest weaknesses are his short attention span, scatterbrain, and clumsiness. He often drives his neighbor Pete up the proverbial wall. Goofy is very calm, lovable, and usually turns the other cheek when Pete insults him (or just doesn\'t realize he\'s been insulted). Though, occasionally, he does get angry and defensive toward Pete when the offense goes too far, but is very forgiving and still considers Pete to be his best friend no matter how often Pete is mean to him.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof (Cameo Role)\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max. Now college-bound, his attempts to distance himself from Goofy and winds up making things worse for him. By finally accepting Goofy as a major part of his life, he was able to find the independence he long sought. Bob Baxter and Steven Trenbirth served as the supervising animators for Max.\n', 'BULLET::::- "An Extremely Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n']

- **Production Quality Insight**: Understanding the production efforts, such as the time taken for voice recording, can inform viewers about the commitment to character authenticity and the overall quality of animated films.

To determine who plays Max's voice in "A Goofy Movie," I need to consider the film's cast and the character's background. "A Goofy Movie," released in 1995, is an animated film that features characters from the Disney universe, specifically from the earlier television series "Goof Troop." 

Max Goof is the son of Goofy, and understanding his character is crucial for identifying the voice actor. In this film, Max is portrayed as a high school student who is active, friendly, and sometimes cunning, reflecting the typical struggles of adolescence, especially in relation to his father, Goofy.

The film also features other notable characters and voice actors, such as Bill Farmer as Goofy and Jim Cummings as Pete, which situates Max within a larger ensemble cast. This context is essential for understanding the dynamics of the film and how Max's character interacts with others.

In summary, knowing that Jason Marsden voices Max allows for a deeper understanding of the character's portrayal and the film's themes, particularly the relationship between a father and son. This knowledge enhances the appreciation of the film's character dynamics and production quality.

### Answer:
Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie."

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine who plays Max's voice in "A Goofy Movie," I need to consider the film's cast and the character's background. "A Goofy Movie," released in 1995, is an animated film that features characters from the Disney universe, specifically focusing on the relationship between Goofy and his son, Max Goof. 

Max Goof is depicted as a high school student navigating typical teenage challenges, including the desire for independence and the embarrassment of having a clumsy father. This character development is significant as it resonates with many viewers who have experienced similar familial dynamics during their adolescence.

The voice actor for Max Goof is Jason Marsden, who took over the role from Dana Hill, who voiced Max in the earlier animated series "Goof Troop." Marsden was a teenager at the time of recording, which aligned well with the character's age and persona. Additionally, while Marsden provided the speaking voice, Aaron Lohr was responsible for Max's singing voice in the film, showcasing the collaborative nature of voice acting in animation.

The film also features other notable voice actors, such as Bill Farmer as Goofy and Jim Cummings as Pete, who reprised their roles from "Goof Troop." This continuity in voice casting helps to maintain the characters' identities across different media.

Moreover, the production of "A Goofy Movie" involved extensive dialogue recording, with creative decisions made regarding the voice of Goofy, highlighting the artistic process behind character development in animation. The film's themes of family, friendship, and self-acceptance have contributed to its lasting cultural impact, particularly among audiences who grew up in the 1990s.

By synthesizing this information, I can conclude that the answer to the question about who plays Max's voice in "A Goofy Movie" is not only about identifying the actor but also about understanding the character's significance and the film's broader implications in animation history.

### Answer:
Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie."

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who plays max voice in a goofy movie
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- "A Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n', 'Most of the main voice cast from "Goof Troop" reprised their roles in "A Goofy Movie", including Bill Farmer as Goofy, Jim Cummings as Pete, and Rob Paulsen as PJ. To conform to his difference in age, Max was played by Jason Marsden, who was in high school at the time, replacing Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the character\'s voice actor. Alternatively, Aaron Lohr did Max\'s singing voice. Other cast members included Kellie Martin as Roxanne, Jenna von Oÿ as Stacey, and Pauly Shore as Bobby Zimuruski. Farmer, who spent 43 days recording dialogue over the span of 2-and-a-half years, was initially asked by Jeffrey Katzenberg to give Goofy a regular speaking voice as opposed to the character\'s signature, cartoonish voice, much to the confusion of Farmer, who insisted that audiences wanted to hear the Goofy they were all familiar with. After recording lines in this manner for a week-and-a-half, according to Farmer, Michael Eisner and Roy E. Disney told Farmer to speak in Goofy\'s original voice, after which the dialogue was rerecorded as such. R&B artist Tevin Campbell provided the singing voice for Powerline, recording the songs "Stand Out" and "I2I". Campbell recorded the songs in front of a green screen while performing his own choreography. The film is dedicated to Pat Buttram, who voiced the emcee at possum park, as he died after finishing voice work for the film.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Mardsen as Max Goof\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof\n', 'WatchMojo.com placed the Nostalgia Critic at #2 on their Top 10 YouTube Movie Critics list. Jacob Davich, who portrayed Linus in the film, "The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl", highly praised the Critic\'s review of the film. Both Bill Farmer, the voice of Goofy, and Jason Marsden, the voice of Max, praised Channel Awesome after watching the Critic\'s editorial, "Is Goofy Secretly Badass?" Animation director Ralph Bakshi praised the review of "Cool World", finding it "very funny". On August 27, 2017, the Critic did a crossover with fellow Channel Awesome critic, Nash Bozard. For "Here There Be Dragons", Bozard\'s review series about fantasy films and adaptations, the Critic and Nash reviewed the short-lived Syfy series "The Dresden Files". Jim Butcher, the author who wrote the novel series on which the series was based, seemed to react positively, tweeting "AHAHAHAHAHAHAHA ICANTSTOPLAUGHINGHAHAHAHAHAH".\n', 'BULLET::::- Maximilian "Max" Goof" (voiced by Dana Hill), is the son and only child of Goofy. He is 11½ years old, and is in the same grade as his best friend P.J. at their junior high school. While he is generally active, alert and friendly, he can also be very cunning and/or coercive when pushed or tricked, sometimes even on par with Pete. He loves his dad, and is close to him, but wishes he would be a little more normal, feeling at times embarrassed by his father\'s clumsy and doting behavior. His interests in the series include skateboarding, video games, rock music, girls, and outwitting bullies.\n', 'BULLET::::- G. G. "Goofy" Goof (voiced by Bill Farmer) is the single father of Max Goof. In the pilot episode, he and his son move next door to the Petes from their trailer home in another city. Goofy\'s biggest weaknesses are his short attention span, scatterbrain, and clumsiness. He often drives his neighbor Pete up the proverbial wall. Goofy is very calm, lovable, and usually turns the other cheek when Pete insults him (or just doesn\'t realize he\'s been insulted). Though, occasionally, he does get angry and defensive toward Pete when the offense goes too far, but is very forgiving and still considers Pete to be his best friend no matter how often Pete is mean to him.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof (Cameo Role)\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max. Now college-bound, his attempts to distance himself from Goofy and winds up making things worse for him. By finally accepting Goofy as a major part of his life, he was able to find the independence he long sought. Bob Baxter and Steven Trenbirth served as the supervising animators for Max.\n', 'BULLET::::- "An Extremely Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n']

question_info.question: who plays max voice in a goofy movie
passages:
BULLET::::- "A Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)
Most of the main voice cast from "Goof Troop" reprised their roles in "A Goofy Movie", including Bill Farmer as Goofy, Jim Cummings as Pete, and Rob Paulsen as PJ. To conform to his difference in age, Max was played by Jason Marsden, who was in high school at the time, replacing Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the character's voice actor. Alternatively, Aaron Lohr did Max's singing voice. Other cast members included Kellie Martin as Roxanne, Jenna von Oÿ as Stacey, and Pauly Shore as Bobby Zimuruski. Farmer, who spent 43 days recording dialogue over the span of 2-and-a-half years, was initially asked by Jeffrey Katzenberg to give Goofy a regular speaking voice as opposed to the character's signature, cartoonish voice, much to the confusion of Farmer, who insisted that audiences wanted to hear the Goofy they were all familiar with. After recording lines in this manner for a week-and-a-half, according to Farmer, Michael Eisner and Roy E. Disney told Farmer to speak in Goofy's original voice, after which the dialogue was rerecorded as such. R&B artist Tevin Campbell provided the singing voice for Powerline, recording the songs "Stand Out" and "I2I". Campbell recorded the songs in front of a green screen while performing his own choreography. The film is dedicated to Pat Buttram, who voiced the emcee at possum park, as he died after finishing voice work for the film.
BULLET::::- Jason Mardsen as Max Goof
BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof
WatchMojo.com placed the Nostalgia Critic at #2 on their Top 10 YouTube Movie Critics list. Jacob Davich, who portrayed Linus in the film, "The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl", highly praised the Critic's review of the film. Both Bill Farmer, the voice of Goofy, and Jason Marsden, the voice of Max, praised Channel Awesome after watching the Critic's editorial, "Is Goofy Secretly Badass?" Animation director Ralph Bakshi praised the review of "Cool World", finding it "very funny". On August 27, 2017, the Critic did a crossover with fellow Channel Awesome critic, Nash Bozard. For "Here There Be Dragons", Bozard's review series about fantasy films and adaptations, the Critic and Nash reviewed the short-lived Syfy series "The Dresden Files". Jim Butcher, the author who wrote the novel series on which the series was based, seemed to react positively, tweeting "AHAHAHAHAHAHAHA ICANTSTOPLAUGHINGHAHAHAHAHAH".
BULLET::::- Maximilian "Max" Goof" (voiced by Dana Hill), is the son and only child of Goofy. He is 11½ years old, and is in the same grade as his best friend P.J. at their junior high school. While he is generally active, alert and friendly, he can also be very cunning and/or coercive when pushed or tricked, sometimes even on par with Pete. He loves his dad, and is close to him, but wishes he would be a little more normal, feeling at times embarrassed by his father's clumsy and doting behavior. His interests in the series include skateboarding, video games, rock music, girls, and outwitting bullies.
BULLET::::- G. G. "Goofy" Goof (voiced by Bill Farmer) is the single father of Max Goof. In the pilot episode, he and his son move next door to the Petes from their trailer home in another city. Goofy's biggest weaknesses are his short attention span, scatterbrain, and clumsiness. He often drives his neighbor Pete up the proverbial wall. Goofy is very calm, lovable, and usually turns the other cheek when Pete insults him (or just doesn't realize he's been insulted). Though, occasionally, he does get angry and defensive toward Pete when the offense goes too far, but is very forgiving and still considers Pete to be his best friend no matter how often Pete is mean to him.
BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof (Cameo Role)
BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max. Now college-bound, his attempts to distance himself from Goofy and winds up making things worse for him. By finally accepting Goofy as a major part of his life, he was able to find the independence he long sought. Bob Baxter and Steven Trenbirth served as the supervising animators for Max.
BULLET::::- "An Extremely Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)
